findings.title: MEE - Missing Events Emission
findings.description: The contract performs actions and state mutations from external methods that do not result in the emission of events.

findings.title: PVC - Price Volatility Concern
findings.description: The contract accumulates tokens from taxes to swap them for ETH, but if `swapTokensAtAmount` is set to a big number, it may lead to significant price volatility due to token price fluctuations.

findings.title: CO - Code Optimization
findings.description: The contract declares a struct named `Distribution` that contains only one property (`marketing`). This struct introduces unnecessary complexity, and declaring a struct for a single variable is redundant.

findings.title: FSA - Fixed Swap Address
findings.description: The swap address is assigned once and cannot be changed, which may prevent the contract from migrating to a new liquidity pool pair or decentralized exchange.

findings.title: RRS - Redundant Require Statement
findings.description: The contract utilizes a `require` statement within the `add` function aiming to prevent overflow errors, but this check is redundant since Solidity version 0.8.0 and later revert on overflow and underflow.

findings.title: RSML - Redundant SafeMath Library
findings.description: The usage of the SafeMath library adds complexity, overhead and increases gas consumption unnecessarily since Solidity versions 0.8.0 and later have native functionality for arithmetic operations that revert to underflow and overflow.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract declares state variables that their value is initialized once in the constructor and are not modified afterwards. The `immutable` declaration can save gas when it is defined.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure they cannot be changed after being set, which decreases gas consumption.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The Solidity style guide is a set of guidelines for writing clean and consistent Solidity code. Adhering to a style guide can help improve the readability and maintainability of the Solidity code, making it easier for others to understand and work with.

findings.title: L05 - Unused State Variable
findings.description: An unused state variable is a state variable that is declared in the contract, but is never used in any of the contract's functions.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version (i.e., any version that is a higher minor or patch version) can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.

findings.title: L20 - Succeeded Transfer Check
findings.description: According to the ERC20 specification, the transfer methods should be checked if the result is successful. Otherwise, the contract may wrongly assume that the transfer has been established.
